bestBHT.bht: Jesus took hold of the man, επιλαβομενος, and took hold of him and healed him, before απελυσεν him from the company. The silence of the critics was a confession of defeat, for they couldn't say it was not lawful to heal on the Sabbath. By touching the man, Jesus showed that the power of healing came from himself. He then dismissed the man, perfectly cured, demonstrating his authority and compassion.

Albert Barnes: They 'could' not say it was not lawful, for the law did not forbid it.
Here was the time for them to make objections if they had any, and not after the man was healed.
By taking hold of him, or touching him, he showed that the power of healing went forth from himself.
Marvin Vincent: Took. Took hold of him. Luke 20:20; 1 Timothy 6:12.
Philip Schaff: Formalism is always thus inconsistent. Their silence was a confession of defeat."
They could attend feasts on the Sabbath, but could not say that it was right to heal the sick."
The rebuke was not given until after the man had been sent away.
Archibald T. Robertson: Took him (επιλαβομενος)... 'took hold of him and healed him.'
Let him go (απελυσεν)... dismissed from the company to get him away from these critics.
John Gill: He took him by the hand, or laid his hands on him; he touched him, and, it may be, stroked the part affected, and in an instant the prodigious swelling of his body came down.
For he who at his rebuke could dry up the sea, could by a touch dry up such a quantity of water, as was in this man's body.
He dismissed him from the table and company, and he went home perfectly cured.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus took hold of the man, as if taking hold of him and healing him, and then dismissed him from the company to get him away from the critics. The silence of the critics was a confession of defeat, for they could not say that it was not lawful to heal on the Sabbath. Jesus showed that the power of healing went forth from himself by touching the man and instantly reducing the swelling. He then sent the man away, perfectly cured, having revealed his authority and compassion.

Jesus took hold of the man, touching and healing him, before dismissing him from the company to remove him from the critics. Their silence was a confession of defeat, for they couldn't deny the lawfulness of healing on the Sabbath. By touching the man, Jesus demonstrated that the power of healing emanated from him. Afterward, he sent the man away, completely cured, showcasing his authority and compassion.

Jesus took hold of the man, επιλαβομενος, and took hold of him and healed him, before απελυσεν him from the company. The silence of the critics was a confession of defeat, for they couldn't say it was not lawful to heal on the Sabbath. By touching the man, Jesus showed that the power of healing came from himself. He then dismissed the man, perfectly cured, demonstrating his authority and compassion.

Jesus took hold of the man, επιλαβομενος, and took hold of him and healed him, before απελυσεν him from the company. The silence of the critics was a confession of defeat, for they couldn't say it was not lawful to heal on the Sabbath. By touching the man, Jesus showed that the power of healing came from himself. He then dismissed the man, perfectly cured, demonstrating his authority and compassion.

Jesus, επιλαβομενος, took hold of the man and took hold of him and healed him, before απελυσεν, dismissing him from the company. The critics' silence was a confession of defeat, as they couldn't deny the lawfulness of healing on the Sabbath. Jesus displayed his authority by touching the man, showing that the power of healing emanated from him. He then sent the man away, perfectly cured, revealing both his authority and compassion.
